standard_metadata.standard_description: Multiply a whole number of up to four digits by a one-digit whole number, and multiply two two-digit numbers, using strategies based on place value and the properties of operations. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.

question.content: The following area model shows $6\times71$ broken into parts.    *The image is not drawn to scale.*    **Find the area of each part.**  $A=$     $B=$    **Find the total area.**   $6\times71={}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A with a width of 6 and a length of 70 and a second part to the right, labeled B, has the same width as part A and a length of 1.

hints.content: The area of the whole rectangle is $6 \times 71$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A with a width of 6 and a second part to the right, labeled B, has the same width as part A. A curved bracket above both parts is labeled 71.

hints.content: To find the area of each part, we multiply its length by its width.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align}\greenE{A}&=\greenE{70\times6} \\\\ &=\greenE{420} \\\\ \purpleD{B}&=\purpleD{1\times6}\\\\ &=\purpleD{6} \end{align}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A equals 70 times 6 with a width of 6 and a length of 70 and a second part to the right, labeled B equals 1 times 6, has the same width as part A and a length of 1.

hints.content: Now we add the areas to find the total.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\greenE{420}+\purpleD{6}=426$  So $6 \times 71 = 426$.

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled 420 with a width of 6 and a length of 70 and a second part to the right, labeled 6, that has the same width as part A and a length of 1.

hints.content: These are the areas:  $\begin{align} &A=420\\\\ &B=6\\\\ &6 \times 71=426 \end{align}$

question.content: The following area model shows $3\times69$ broken into parts.    *The image is not drawn to scale.*    **Find the area of each part.**  $A=$     $B=$    **Find the total area.**   $3\times69={}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A with a width of 3 and a length of 60 and a second part to the right, labeled B, has the same width as part A and a length of 9.

hints.content: The area of the whole rectangle is $3 \times 69$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A with a width of 3 and a second part to the right, labeled B, has the same width as part A. A curved bracket above both parts is labeled 69.

hints.content: To find the area of each part, we multiply its length by its width.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align}\greenE{A}&=\greenE{60\times3} \\\\ &=\greenE{180} \\\\ \purpleD{B}&=\purpleD{9\times3}\\\\ &=\purpleD{27} \end{align}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A equals 60 times 3 with a width of 3 and a length of 60 and a second part to the right, labeled B equals 9 times 3, has the same width as part A and a length of 9.

hints.content: Now we add the areas to find the total.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\greenE{180}+\purpleD{27}=207$  So $3 \times 69 = 207$.

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled 180 with a width of 3 and a length of 60 and a second part to the right, labeled 27, that has the same width as part A and a length of 9.

hints.content: These are the areas:  $\begin{align} &A=180\\\\ &B=27\\\\ &3 \times69=207 \end{align}$

question.content: The following area model shows $4\times92$ broken into parts.    *The image is not drawn to scale.*    **Find the area of each part.**  $A=$     $B=$    **Find the total area.**   $4\times92={}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A with a width of 4 and a length of 90 and a second part to the right, labeled B, has the same width as part A and a length of 2.

hints.content: The area of the whole rectangle is $4 \times 92$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A with a width of 4 and a second part to the right, labeled B, has the same width as part A. A curved bracket above both parts is labeled 92.

hints.content: To find the area of each part, we multiply its length by its width.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align}\greenE{A}&=\greenE{90\times4} \\\\ &=\greenE{360} \\\\ \purpleD{B}&=\purpleD{2\times4}\\\\ &=\purpleD{8} \end{align}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A equals 90 times 4 with a width of 4 and a length of 90 and a second part to the right, labeled B equals 2 times 4, has the same width as part A and a length of 2.

hints.content: Now we add the areas to find the total.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\greenE{360}+\purpleD{8}=368$  So $4 \times 92 = 368$.

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled 360 with a width of 4 and a length of 90 and a second part to the right, labeled 8, that has the same width as part A and a length of 2.

hints.content: These are the areas:  $\begin{align} &A=360\\\\ &B=8\\\\ &4 \times92=368 \end{align}$

question.content: The following area model shows $7\times88$ broken into parts.    *The image is not drawn to scale.*    **Find the area of each part.**  $A=$     $B=$    **Find the total area.**   $7\times88={}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A with a width of 7 and a length of 80 and a second part to the right, labeled B, has the same width as part A and a length of 8.

hints.content: The area of the whole rectangle is $7 \times 88$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A with a width of 7 and a second part to the right, labeled B, has the same width as part A. A curved bracket above both parts is labeled 88.

hints.content: To find the area of each part, we multiply its length by its width.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align}\greenE{A}&=\greenE{80\times7} \\\\ &=\greenE{560} \\\\ \purpleD{B}&=\purpleD{8\times7}\\\\ &=\purpleD{56} \end{align}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A equals 80 times 7 with a width of 7 and a length of 80 and a second part to the right, labeled B equals 8 times 7, has the same width as part A and a length of 8.

hints.content: Now we add the areas to find the total.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\greenE{560}+\purpleD{56}=616$  So $7 \times 88 = 616$.

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled 560 with a width of 7 and a length of 80 and a second part to the right, labeled 56, that has the same width as part A and a length of 8.

hints.content: These are the areas:  $\begin{align} &A=560\\\\ &B=56\\\\ &7 \times 88=616 \end{align}$

question.content: The following area model shows $8\times45$ broken into parts.    *The image is not drawn to scale.*    **Find the area of each part.**  $A=$     $B=$    **Find the total area.**   $8\times45={}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A with a width of 8 and a length of 40 and a second part to the right, labeled B, has the same width as part A and a length of 5.

hints.content: The area of the whole rectangle is $8 \times 45$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A with a width of 8 and a second part to the right, labeled B, has the same width as part A. A curved bracket above both parts is labeled 45.

hints.content: To find the area of each part, we multiply its length by its width.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align}\greenE{A}&=\greenE{40\times8} \\\\ &=\greenE{320} \\\\ \purpleD{B}&=\purpleD{5\times8}\\\\ &=\purpleD{40} \end{align}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A equals 40 times 8 with a width of 8 and a length of 40 and a second part to the right, labeled B equals 5 times 8, has the same width as part A and a length of 5.

hints.content: Now we add the areas to find the total.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\greenE{320}+\purpleD{40}=360$  So $8 \times 45 = 360$.

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled 320 with a width of 8 and a length of 40 and a second part to the right, labeled 40, that has the same width as part A and a length of 5.

hints.content: These are the areas:  $\begin{align} &A=320\\\\ &B=40\\\\ &8 \times 45=360 \end{align}$

question.content: The following area model shows $9\times54$ broken into parts.    *The image is not drawn to scale.*    **Find the area of each part.**  $A=$     $B=$     **Find the total area.**   $9\times54={}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A with a width of 9 and a length of 50 and a second part to the right, labeled B, has the same width as part A and a length of 4.

hints.content: The area of the whole rectangle is $9 \times 54$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A with a width of 9 and a second part to the right, labeled B, has the same width as part A. A curved bracket above both parts is labeled 54.

hints.content: To find the area of each part, we multiply its length by its width.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align}\greenE{A}&=\greenE{50\times9} \\\\ &=\greenE{450} \\\\ \purpleD{B}&=\purpleD{4\times9}\\\\ &=\purpleD{36} \end{align}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A equals 50 times 9 with a width of 9 and a length of 50 and a second part to the right, labeled B equals 4 times 9, has the same width as part A and a length of 4.

hints.content: Now we add the areas to find the total.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\greenE{450}+\purpleD{36}=486$  So $9 \times 54 = 486$.

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled 450 with a width of 9 and a length of 50 and a second part to the right, labeled 36, that has the same width as part A and a length of 4.

hints.content: These are the areas:  $\begin{align} &A=450\\\\ &B=36\\\\ &9 \times 54=486 \end{align}$

question.content: The following area model shows $57\times2$ broken into parts.    *The image is not drawn to scale.*    **Find the area of each part.**    $A=$      $B=$    **Find the total area.**   $57\times2={}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A with a width of 2 and a length of 50 and a second part to the right, labeled B, has the same width as part A and a length of 7.

hints.content: The area of the whole rectangle is $57 \times2$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A with a width of 2 and a second part to the right, labeled B, has the same width as part A. A curved bracket above both parts is labeled 57.

hints.content: To find the area of the whole, we add the area of each part.  $\greenE{A}+\purpleD{B}=57 \times2$

To find the area of each part, we multiply its length by its width.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align}\greenE{A}&=\greenE{50\times2} \\\\ &=\greenE{100} \\\\ \purpleD{B}&=\purpleD{7\times2}\\\\ &=\purpleD{14} \end{align}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A equals 50 times 2 with a width of 2 and a length of 50 and a second part to the right, labeled B equals 7 times 2, has the same width as part A and a length of 7.

hints.content: Now we add the areas to find the total.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\greenE{100}+\purpleD{14}=114$  So $57 \times 2 = 114$.

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled 100 with a width of 2 and a length of 50 and a second part to the right, labeled 14, that has the same width as part A and a length of 7.

hints.content: These are the areas:  $\begin{align} &A=100\\\\ &B=14\\\\ &57 \times 2=114 \end{align}$

question.content: The following area model shows $48\times3$ broken into parts.    *The image is not drawn to scale.*    **Find the area of each part.**    $A=$      $B=$    **Find the total area.**   $48\times3={}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A with a width of 3 and a length of 40 and a second part to the right, labeled B, has the same width as part A and a length of 8.

hints.content: The area of the whole rectangle is $48 \times3$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A with a width of 3 and a second part to the right, labeled B, has the same width as part A. A curved bracket above both parts is labeled 48.

hints.content: To find the area of the whole, we add the area of each part.  $\greenE{A}+\purpleD{B}=48 \times3$

To find the area of each part, we multiply its length by its width.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align}\greenE{A}&=\greenE{40\times3} \\\\ &=\greenE{120} \\\\ \purpleD{B}&=\purpleD{8\times3}\\\\ &=\purpleD{24} \end{align}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A equals 40 times 3 with a width of 3 and a length of 40 and a second part to the right, labeled B equals 8 times 3, has the same width as part A and a length of 8.

hints.content: Now we add the areas to find the total.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\greenE{120}+\purpleD{24}=144$  So $48 \times 3 = 144$.

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled 120 with a width of 3 and a length of 40 and a second part to the right, labeled 24, that has the same width as part A and a length of 8.

hints.content: These are the areas:  $\begin{align} &A=120\\\\ &B=24\\\\ &48 \times 3=144 \end{align}$

question.content: The following area model shows $62\times4$ broken into parts.    *The image is not drawn to scale.*    **Find the area of each part.**    $A=$      $B=$    **Find the total area.**   $62\times4={}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A with a width of 4 and a length of 60 and a second part to the right, labeled B, has the same width as part A and a length of 2.

hints.content: The area of the whole rectangle is $62 \times4$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A with a width of 4 and a second part to the right, labeled B, has the same width as part A. A curved bracket above both parts is labeled 62.

hints.content: To find the area of the whole, we add the area of each part.  $\greenE{A}+\purpleD{B}=62 \times4$

To find the area of each part, we multiply its length by its width.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align}\greenE{A}&=\greenE{60\times4} \\\\ &=\greenE{240} \\\\ \purpleD{B}&=\purpleD{2\times4}\\\\ &=\purpleD{8} \end{align}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A equals 60 times 4 with a width of 4 and a length of 60 and a second part to the right, labeled B equals 2 times 4, has the same width as part A and a length of 2.

hints.content: Now we add the areas to find the total.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\greenE{240}+\purpleD{8}=248$  So $62 \times 4 = 248$.

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled 240 with a width of 4 and a length of 60 and a second part to the right, labeled 8, that has the same width as part A and a length of 2.

hints.content: These are the areas:  $\begin{align} &A=240\\\\ &B=8\\\\ &62 \times 4=248 \end{align}$

question.content: The following area model shows $29\times5$ broken into parts.    *The image is not drawn to scale.*   **Find the area of each part.**      $A=$      $B=$    **Find the total area.**   $29\times5={}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A with a width of 5 and a length of 20 and a second part to the right, labeled B, has the same width as part A and a length of 9.

hints.content: The area of the whole rectangle is $29 \times5$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A with a width of 5 and a second part to the right, labeled B, has the same width as part A. A curved bracket above both parts is labeled 29.

hints.content: To find the area of the whole, we add the area of each part.  $\greenE{A}+\purpleD{B}=29 \times5$

To find the area of each part, we multiply its length by its width.   [[☃ image 1]]    $\begin{align}\greenE{A}&=\greenE{20\times5} \\\\ &=\greenE{100} \\\\ \purpleD{B}&=\purpleD{9\times5}\\\\ &=\purpleD{45} \end{align}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A = 20 x 5 with a width of 5 and a length of 20 and a second part to the right, labeled B = 9 x 5, has the same width as part A and a length of 9.

hints.content: Now we add the areas to find the total.  [[☃ image 1]]   $\greenE{100}+\purpleD{45}=145$  So $29 \times 5 = 145$.

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled 100 with a width of 5 and a length of 20 and a second part to the right, labeled 45, that has the same width as part A and a length of 9.

hints.content: These are the areas:  $\begin{align} &A=100\\\\ &B=45\\\\ &29 \times 5=145 \end{align}$

question.content: The following area model shows $93\times7$ broken into parts.    *The image is not drawn to scale.*    **Find the area of each part.**  $A=$    $B=$    **Find the total area.**   $93 \times 7 ={}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A with a width of 7 and a length of 90 and a second part to the right, labeled B, has the same width as part A and a length of 3.

hints.content: The area of the whole rectangle is $93 \times 7$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A with a width of 7 and a second part to the right, labeled B, has the same width as part A. A curved bracket above both parts is labeled 93.

hints.content: To find the area of the whole, we add the area of each part.  $\greenE{A}+\purpleD{B}=93 \times 7$

To find the area of each part, we multiply its length by its width.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align}\greenE{A}&=\greenE{90\times7} \\\\ &=\greenE{630} \\\\ \purpleD{B}&=\purpleD{3\times7}\\\\ &=\purpleD{21} \end{align}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A equals 90 times 7 with a width of 7 and a length of 90 and a second part to the right, labeled B equals 3 times 7, has the same width as part A and a length of 3.

hints.content: Now we add the areas to find the total.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\greenE{630}+\purpleD{21}=651$  So $93 \times 7 = 651$.

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled 630 with a width of 7 and a length of 90 and a second part to the right, labeled 21, that has the same width as part A and a length of 3.

hints.content: These are the areas:  $\begin{align} &A=630\\\\ &B=21\\\\ &93 \times 7=651 \end{align}$

question.content: The following area model shows $37\times9$ broken into parts.    *The image is not drawn to scale.*    **Find the area of each part.**    $A=$      $B=$    **Find the total area.**   $37\times9={}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A with a width of 9 and a length of 30 and a second part to the right, labeled B, has the same width as part A and a length of 7.

hints.content: The area of the whole rectangle is $37 \times9$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A with a width of 9 and a second part to the right, labeled B, has the same width as part A. A curved bracket above both parts is labeled 37.

hints.content: To find the area of the whole, we add the area of each part.  $\greenE{A}+\purpleD{B}=37 \times 9$

To find the area of each part, we multiply its length by its width.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align}\greenE{A}&=\greenE{30\times9} \\\\ &=\greenE{270} \\\\ \purpleD{B}&=\purpleD{7\times9}\\\\ &=\purpleD{63} \end{align}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled A equals 30 times 9 with a width of 9 and a length of 30 and a second part to the right, labeled B equals 7 times 9, has the same width as part A and a length of 7.

hints.content: Now we add the areas to find the total.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\greenE{270}+\purpleD{63}=333$  So $37 \times 9 = 333$.

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 2 unequal parts, a first part labeled 270 with a width of 9 and a length of 30 and a second part to the right, labeled 63, that has the same width as part A and a length of 7.

hints.content: These are the areas:  $\begin{align} &A=270\\\\ &B=63\\\\ &37 \times 9=333 \end{align}$
